This commit introduces a discrepancy that might not be immediately obvious, though.

```
import requests

# Times out
requests.timeout = 0.000001
requests.get('http://google.com')

# Doesn't time out
requests.settings.timeout = 0.00001
requests.get('http://google.com')
```
Hmm, It times out for me.

Your internet connection. I want it.

```
Python 2.7 (r27:82500, Apr 21 2011, 13:38:41) 
[GCC 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5664)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import requests
>>> requests.settings.timeout = 0.000001
>>> requests.get('http://google.com')
<Response [200]>
```

They do at times. Depends on my mood.

First rule of open source development: don't take yourself too seriously. 

Of course I know how to make a 'proper' commit message. Doesn't mean I always should.
Everything has a time and place.

You can certainly write any commit messages you want, this is open source and your work is appreciated much, be it with good commit messages or without them, code is what matters anyway. But the issue with unreadable commit messages is that they are wasting other peoples' time because they make it harder to follow the development. If commit message doesn't describe what happend developer is forced to look at source code every time for every commit to see if changes will affect her.

Don't worry — If the change is important, you'll know.

Help on dict.pop:

> D.pop(k[,d]) -> v, remove specified key and return the corresponding value.
> If key is not found, d is returned if given, otherwise KeyError is raised

So `s = kwargs.pop('session') if 'session' in kwargs else sessions.session()` can be rewritten as `s = kwargs.pop('session', sessions.session())`. Or am i wrong?
What's the point of coercing into list? `for k, v in local_kwarg.items():` works exactly the same.

They are not exactly the same. In your version, a new session object is created to send as an argument to `.pop` even if the `'session'` already exists in the dict. But in my version, because of python's short circuiting, if the `'session'` already exists in the dict, a new on won't be created, i.e., the `session.session()` code is not evaluated.

Why _are_ we merging these? We're removing the ability for users of requests to distinguish between

``` http
X-Header: a
X-Header: b
```

and

``` http
X-Header: a, b
```

This is not ideal.
https://github.com/shazow/urllib3/issues/3
It's actually coercing to a tuple, which already exists because of the `,`. Just a little easier to read :)
i mean the list() construct. items() returns iterator, over which for loop will iterate normally. or am i wrong?
Ah, yes. I think I had a reason for that..
It’s actually called a scheme, not schema.

Well, I seldom see people use context managers as you described in #1036 but maybe I'm just not with the times.

I'm used to seeing something akin to:

``` python
with requests.session() as s:
     r_1 = s.get(url_1)
     # ...
     r_n = s.get(url_n)
```

And on a multithreaded app, it should generate different context managers, so I'm having trouble seeing where this would become an issue. Could you provide some sample code that breaks this? I'm guessing your usage is something along the lines of:

``` python

s = requests.session()

# ... 

with s:
     r_1 = s.get(url_1)
```

But then this begs the question, why use a with statement? `s` is already defined, just use `s` directly.

Is there a reason why this got removed?

A very specific one. It wasn't good design in the first place. Attributes shouldn't through errors on decoding JSON, but not throwing an error would be misleading and might make a user think there was no JSON. As a method, it is perfectly legal for it through an exception. And that's how it should be.

It seems to me that the original code is more correct.  "raise" by itself re-raises the original exception while preserving the original traceback context.  "raise e" re-raises but from  a different code location, so the traceback will be different (it hides the original location of the error).

This is only true if the 401 response is not content-aware; there's no fundamental link between the status code and the content type of the response.
Is this intentional?  It doesn't actually do anything.
It pre-loads the content. If you look at `r.content` it is a method that does all the right stuff.
OK.... maybe my Python fu is not strong enough, but if it's a method should it not have `()` on it?

It is decorated with `property` which makes its invocation look as though you're working with a property (attribute) of the object. This is the [relevant code](https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/blob/e91ee0e2461cc9b6822e7c3cc422038604ace08d/requests/models.py#L622..L644). It memoizes the content as a `bytes` object and will read in the body of the `urrlib3.HTTPResponse` object once so that it isn't hit more than once (not that it is a specifically expensive call).

A little late to the party, but I'm a little unsure about this part of the code..

A read timeout only kicks in if the time between bytes on the server exceeds the timeout. So if the read timeout is set to 30 seconds and the server sends one byte every 29 seconds, the timeout will never get hit. You can test this for yourself by running https://github.com/kevinburke/hamms#connection-level-errors and hitting port 5506 with a 10 second timeout, the request will take about two minutes.

It's still perfectly valid, I think, to try and stream a recording or something, and want to timeout if the server is too slow to begin streaming the request to you.
Uh, is that not what this code does?

Gah, it's a little bit more complicated than that because the code isn't working properly. there's an issue with the timeout code I wrote that makes both branches of this if statement behave the same way. see the issue here: https://github.com/shazow/urllib3/issues/261

This now causes non-RFC compliant JSON encoded to something other than a UTF codec and _no_ charset set in the response, to fail. `guess_json_utf()` will still return `UTF-8` for most codecs (latin-1, latin-2, etc.). Removing the first `try:` block now breaks handling such responses.

You should have a code style documentation if you are strictly opposed to some PEP8 guidelines.

Especially I find this really ugly compared to the original version:

```
gen = self.resolve_redirects(r, request,
    stream=stream,
    timeout=timeout,
    verify=verify,
    cert=cert,
    proxies=proxies)
```

Plus this violates PEP8 (E128, continuation line under-indented).

PEP8 conform alternative would be

```
gen = self.resolve_redirects(
    r, request,
    stream=stream,
    timeout=timeout,
    verify=verify,
    cert=cert,
    proxies=proxies)
```
BTW, this is from c042c08179cae7.

Can you explain, why you added that line? Is it only to save the import of `requests.utils` when using it, or why? Thanks in advance.

It ensures that all the submodules are immediately available in the namespace, rather than requiring separate imports.

Without it, you get this:

``` python
>>> import requests
>>> requests.utils
AttributeError: module 'requests' has no attribute 'utils'
```

With it, you get

``` python
>>> import requests
>>> requests.utils
<module 'requests.utils' from 'wherever'>
```

This may be a little overkill since the current uses for `merge_cookies` supplies an empty `CookieJar`, but I didn't want people to unintentionally override a policy and possibly send unwanted cookies.
This may cause confusion for some use cases. I figured it was a better default to prevent accidental override and unintentional cookie transfer than always overriding the policy.

Is there a cross-reference link to the specification or RFC for prohibiting non-string values? According to [RFC7230 §3.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.2), the BNF for header field values is:

```
HTAB           =  %x09 ; horizontal tab
SP             =  %x20
CR             =  %x0D ; carriage return
LF             =  %x0A ; linefeed
CRLF           =  CR LF ; Internet standard newline
VCHAR          =  %x21-7E ; visible (printing) characters

obs-fold       = CRLF 1*( SP / HTAB )
obs-text       = %x80-FF

field-vchar    = VCHAR / obs-text

field-content  = field-vchar [ 1*( SP / HTAB ) field-vchar ]
               = (VCHAR / obs-text) [ 1*( SP / HTAB ) (VCHAR / obs-text) ]
               = (VCHAR / %x80-FF) [ 1*( SP / HTAB ) (VCHAR / %x80-FF) ]

field-value    = *( field-content / obs-fold )
               = *( ((VCHAR / %x80-FF) [ 1*( SP / HTAB ) (VCHAR / %x80-FF) ]) / (CRLF 1*( SP / HTAB )) )
```

This question doesn't make any sense. The RFC doesn't forbid non-string values in any literal sense because it's prohibiting something that cannot be done. Header fields are allowed to contain visible characters, the high bytes, and whitespace. Definitionally, then, they are strings (or at least stringish). We cannot, for example, send integers in big-endian form.

What Requests is refusing to do is _guess_ how you want header field values to be rendered. We are now requiring that you pass us a string, which is something that we then do not have to do any guessing with.

So this means requests now expects  callers to manually encode header fields that are non-string values?

This is breaking some service interface code I'm using and it will take some time to go through and update all of it.

It seems like a better approach would be to auto encode values the old way (or do whatever was being done before) and warn users that a breaking change to requests is coming in the future to give users time to update their code.

What was the old encoding method used?

@sthompson0 the documentation has always stated that we expect string values for headers. We didn't have an old encoding method. It was always whatever httplib felt like encoding for whatever version of Python you used. I'm sorry that enforcing our API has broken your service interface code, but we didn't write that code and are under no obligation to fix this for you at the wrong level.
This actually would need to be added back in if we want to maintain the 'Content-Length: 0' default for verbs that should have a body but don't.
Also, a test for this would probably be useful.
Agreed, I think we need a test and to re-add this logic in some form.

gevent:

> Coroutine-based concurrency library for Python

上个提交引入了gevent, 现在先找eventlet,如果没有则使用gevent, 因为作者觉得eventlet更好一些.
eventlet的实现是使用moneky patch的方式将Python的标准网络库进行了修改,gevent是基于libevent的, 1.0以后改为了基于libev, 这些都是C语言实现的网络并发处理的库.
